However, experience both in Australia and overseas has shown that the financiers are more closely associated with the profits of crime. That experience also shows that cash is an important part of financing criminal activity.

This Bill will give law enforcement agencies the ability to monitor the movement of large amounts of cash and thus to identify the recipients of proceeds of crime. The legislation is consistent with calls by a number of royal commissions and other inquiries in recent years for stronger measures to deal with the widespread abuse of the facilities of financial institutions in relation to tax fraud and other criminal activities. The Bill implements a scheme for the reporting of certain large currency transactions conducted through various institutions and certain transfers of currency into and out of Australia.

The reporting of large scale cash transactions conducted through certain types of cash dealers, the reporting of the export of foreign currency and the reporting of the import of foreign and Australian currency, together with the verification of the identity of persons who open, or operate, accounts with certain financial institutions, are essential measures to enable the cash economy to be controlled and to minimise tax evasion. The reports will also be of great value in following the money trail in relation to proceeds of all criminal activities, including tax evasion, and in detecting financiers of criminal activity such as drug trafficking. The thrust of the scheme is broadly similar to the successful scheme in operation in the United States.

My recent visit to the United States has confirmed my conviction that the ability to monitor the movements of large amounts of cash, both domestically and internationally, is an essential aspect of the fight against organised crime and has very substantial benefits in the effective collection of revenue. United States officials informed me that several hundred million dollars were recovered last year from their export/ import reporting requirements alone.
Objects of Bill

The principal object of the Bill is to facilitate the administration and enforcement of the taxation laws. Further objects of the Bill are to facilitate the administration and enforcement of laws of the Commonwealth, and of a Territory, and to make information collected under the Bill available to State law enforcement authorities to facilitate the administration and enforcement of State laws.
Content of Bill

The Bill provides for the reporting of certain cash transactions and transfers, establishes the Cash Transaction Reports Agency and, in addition, imposes certain obligations on financial institutions in relation to the opening and operation of accounts.
Cash Transaction Reports

The Bill requires cash dealers to report to the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. These dealers include financial institutions and others, such as bookmakers and casinos, who have the capacity to receive and co-mingle large amounts of cash. They will report cash transactions to which the dealer is a party, and which involve currency in excess of $10,000. All transactions, other than exempt transactions, must be reported. Exemptions may be granted to certain high cash flow businesses, to employers for payroll withdrawals, to Government agencies, and may relate to individual transactions or to certain classes of transactions. Financial institutions will be required to maintain an exemption register. The Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency will have access to any exemption register and will have power to direct a financial institution to remove or amend any entry in the exemption register maintained by the institution.
Reports Relating to Import and Export Currency

The Government considers it essential to be able to monitor the movement of funds into, and out of, Australia and has therefore provided the Cash Transaction Reports Agency with a monitoring role in relation to the export of foreign currency, and the import of any currency, in excess of $5,000. At the present time, tax clearances are required before certain types of funds can be moved overseas and the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations contain a prohibition on the export of Australian currency in excess of $5,000. No other checks are maintained on the movement of funds into or out of Australia. As a further check on the movement, and destination, of funds any person in Australia who receives Australian or foreign, currency from a place outside Australia will be required to report the receipt of those funds to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency if the value of the currency involved exceeds $5,000.

The Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations confer on Customs and police officers wide-ranging powers to question persons leaving Australia and to inspect their luggage for the purpose of ascertaining currency violations and the Bill provides those officers with similar powers in relation to ensuring that relevant cash transaction reports have been filed.
Access to CTR Information

The legislation provides that all CTR information is to be provided to the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. The Agency is to make the information available to the Commissioner of taxation on a direct and unrestricted basis. Other law enforcement agencies including the Australian Customs Service, the National Crime Authority and State law enforcement agencies may also seek access to CTR information. All CTR information may be utilised by relevant agencies for both evidentiary and investigative purposes.
Obligations in Relation to the Opening and Operation of Accounts

Following the recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and the continued failure of the Senate to pass the Australia Card legislation which would provide an effective weapon against tax evasion and fraud, the Government considers it essential to include in this Bill provisions dealing with the verification of the identity of persons opening, and operating, accounts with financial institutions. The system for the verification of account holders provided in this legislation places some obligations on financial institutions and their customers but it should be borne in mind that banks already require similar information before accounts can be opened. The Bill has been drafted to allow for the use of the Australia Card as a means of verifying accounts. However, given the Senate's failure to pass the Australia Card legislation, it has been necessary to provide alternative means of verification pending the passage of the Australia Card legislation.
Enforcement

Part IV of the Bill creates offences of structuring transactions and transfers to avoid the reporting requirements, failure to comply with, and providing false and misleading information in purported compliance with the Bill. An injunction mechanism in relation to breaches of the legislation, particularly where there is a contravention committed by an agency which would otherwise fall within the shield of the Crown, is also available.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill will have only a modest impact on cash dealers required to report cash transaction information as the legislation provides sufficient flexibility to enable the Director of the Agency to develop the most cost-effective measures for cash dealers to record and communicate information to the Agency. In relation to the public sector, the legislation will require the establishment of a Cash Transaction Reports Agency and the purchase of sophisticated computer facilities for the Agency. However, the Australian Taxation Office projects an increase in tax revenue alone of some $30m. In addition, the United States' experience indicates that there will be significant criminal law enforcement benefits. Based on annual Agency running costs of $2m per annum, with an extra $1m for establishing computer facilities, the measures are clearly cost-effective. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1987-88[COGNATE BILLS:SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1987-88SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1987-88]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1987-88, and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Continuing what I was saying earlier-(Quorum formed) I thank the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) for calling the quorum and giving me such an attentive audience. In speaking to Supply Bill (No. 1) 1987-88, I would like to devote some of my comments to the allocations to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Like most honourable members, I have many veterans in my electorate and I always listen very carefully to their representations.

SPEECH.PARA: A few months ago the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) stirred up the sub-branches of the Returned Services League in my electorate by saying that this Government was going to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs. He engaged in some political gimmickry by sending telegrams to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), demanding that the Department of Veterans' Affairs not be abolished. He claimed to be receiving 80 letters a day on the issue. As well, he called on me to state where I stood on the issue. I must say that I also received dozens of individual letters and letters from each of the RSL sub-branches. I wrote back to each of them, quoting a reply from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) which stated:
The Prime Minister has given a firm assurance, not only to me personally-
that, is the Minister-
but also to the Parliamentary Labor Party that the Department of Veterans' Affairs will be retained.
I suggested to each letter writer that he also write to Liberal members seeking an assurance on the future of the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many did?

—I do not know how many did; I am coming to that. But what have we seen in the latest reshuffle? There is no separate shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs in the Liberal Party of Australia. Senator Austin Lewis has had that tacked on to his responsibility for local government and Territories. Even the National Party of Australia has given the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) the portfolio of veterans' affairs as well as immigration and ethnic affairs and Aboriginal affairs. There is no doubt that in the unlikely event of the Liberals ever gaining office-we know that they will not-they would amalgamate the Department of Veterans' Affairs with the Department of Social Security. Such a change would drastically affect the benefits and rights of veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, what the conservatives are planning to do is a result of the pressures being exerted on them by the forces of darkness, that is, the forces of the New Right in this country which in various ways have published documents and made statements that there ought to be drastic reductions in the number of departments and in the role of the Public Service. Some have gone so far as to suggest the abolition of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Late last year a deputation from the RSL met with the honourable member for Bennelong who, according to the national newsletter of the RSL, refused to give a commitment that the Department of Veterans' Affairs would be retained.

When there is disarray in the ranks of the conservative parties, documents seem to have the capacity to fall off the back of trucks with greater rapidity than in normal times. A document published in the Australian Financial Review suggested that the Department of Veterans' Affairs would be amalgamated with the Department of Social Security and would operate under one Minister. These policies coming from the conservative side of politics create a great deal of confusion and concern in the ranks of veterans. I might add that the honourable member for Gilmore has been very silent on the issue lately. Why is it that he is now so silent on the issue of the future of the Department of Veterans' Affairs? He was not so silent a few months ago. I repeat that the Hawke Labor Government-we can see it in the allocation for the Department in this legislation-will retain a separate Department of Veterans' Affairs while ever there is a need for it.

I now turn to the allocation for the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment. One of the real difficulties in this House is the dilemma faced by young, ambitious members who are keen to get publicity. Such an example is the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who is now the shadow spokesperson for arts, heritage and environment. No one in this chamber has been more critical over the past two years of grants to the arts, especially community arts, than the honourable member for Mayo. He must now be burning the midnight oil reading his speeches. Time and again he made speeches just to get a bit of cheap publicity. Let me assure the honourable member that he is not the only one going through all the speeches he made in this chamber on the arts. Many honourable members on this side and many people in the arts community are going through his speeches and will be repeating them to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm flattered.

—The honourable member who claims that he is flattered at this attention might answer one question: What is the Opposition's approach to arm's length funding? Is it in agreement with that or not? Many people in the community want to know the Opposition's approach to that. Of course, the famous Waste Watch Committee, of which he was a member, wanted to direct attention away from the Liberals' lack of policies; just as they have no taxation policy, they have no arts policy. Perhaps if they came up with a policy and released it for public debate we would know where they stood on these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to some of the criticisms made by the famous Waste Watch Committee. Professor Scott, the Chairman of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, said that perhaps a project entitled `Uninformed criticism of ARGS grants 1987-88' would be a high priority for future funding so that these criticisms can be exposed for the shallow understanding of the world of research that they are. How can one judge the merits of a project by its title alone? Does one select a book to read purely by its title? If so, one is in for a shock. As You Like It would, no doubt, be a soft pornographic play; Sleeper Awake, possibly a book on religious meditations; and Paradise Lost, the sequel to a recent John Mortimer television series. Ludicrous it may be, but it appears to be the basis on which one per cent of the grants was labelled wasteful. Was any attempt made to discover the real nature of the despised projects? I suspect that the only reason that some of the scientific projects were not also categorised as wasteful was that the Waste Watch Committee could not understand the titles. A recent critical editorial stated:
Australia's standing depends on the quality of our academic work, not just the subjects under research.

How true that is. Every one of these despised projects has been assessed by experts in the field, often from overseas. The competition for grants is immense. A high proportion of applicants fail and the quality of the work of the successful is internationally recognised. The inference may be that such projects should be funded by research workers at their own expense. This is, alas, impracticable. Therefore, it must be presumed that the projects should not be attempted. Is Australia then to opt out of all research judged as irrelevant by groups such as the Waste Watch Committee? It is to be wondered whether Australia gets more credit from having the recognised world expert on the Greek vases of southern Italy quite literally feted wherever he goes and awarded dozens of prizes for his work, or from the disappointing performances of an athlete supported by tens of thousands of dollars of government subsidies.

TALK.START.PARA: —You hate sportsmen, don't you?

—As was written, a research project must be judged by its quality, by a detailed examination of its merits and expert assessment, not by a political snap judgment based on its title alone. The former is what the Australian research grants scheme attempts to do. It would be tragic for the future position of Australia as a country of genuine influence in the world if this were the only type of research sponsored by government. The Waste Watch Committee's denunciation of research and, by implication, teaching, in classical studies would particularly upset Australians of Greek or Italian origin. Those groups in our community can rightly take a pride in the contributions of their forebears to the world's cultural heritage, and they strongly support the opportunities within our education system for the study of Greek and Roman civilisations.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion: The honourable member for Mayo interjected that I must be opposed to sport. That is absolute rubbish. All we are asking for is a fair allocation of the resources that are available. If people, such as members of the Waste Watch Committee, are to criticise projects, they should at least get their facts right. They should do a little bit of research before they criticise research projects. They would benefit from doing so. There may well be room for criticism, but at least it would be justified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a real pleasure to follow the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) in this debate when I now realise that he is a sportsman. When I look at him I say to myself: `There is no way in the world that he would make a Queensland team'. We do not have room for little, round fat fellas who run out of gas. Obviously, I can only presume that he would be a member of a New South Wales team which Queensland religiously beats. Being defeated will be good training for him because after the next election he will be sitting on this side of the House. However, I am glad to hear that he is interested in sport.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating the Supply Bills, rather ironically, on the day of the May statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), when all of us expect the Treasurer to announce severe but realistic and fair cuts in government spending. The National Party of Australia will be looking for substantial and meaningful expenditure cuts which limit government involvement in people's lives, which will rein in inflation and high interest rates and build confidence so that Australians can make the difficult decisions that are necessary to create a competitive Australia. We notice from share market and currency market activities in recent days that foreign investors also are expecting tough spending cuts in tonight's mini-Budget. On behalf of all concerned Australians, I make a plea, even at this eleventh hour, to the Treasurer not to disappoint us. In return, I request the Australian public to try to understand the difficulties our economy is in. All of us should accept the cuts which need to be made so economic prosperity can return to this country. All of us must realise that we have a very difficult task ahead.

It has always disappointed me that, on average, Australians work only 231 out of the 365 days in a calendar year. I submit, without any fear of bitterness, that on the whole all of us need to work harder. We need to produce more at a given time. We need to have greater enthusiasm to regain our international trading position. I am delighted that the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) is at the table, because I want to address a few comments to the sum of $25.4m allocated in the Supply Bills to the Australian Trade Commission, reflecting a higher provision for export market development grants. We need to realise that Australia has declined in importance as a world trader in the past 30 years. We are down from 2.6 to 1.3 per cent in terms of world trade in that period, which takes us from eighth position to twenty-third position. One of the reasons is that our emphasis has been on the export of raw materials at a time when strong growth in international trade was in manufacturing and services. Nearly 40 per cent of our export income is derived from just four commodities-coal, wheat, wool and iron ore. Moreover, in excess of 50 per cent of exports are directed to just four countries-Japan, the United States of America, China and New Zealand. The pressures that we have on costs, high interest rates and inflation bring into sharp focus the need for Australia to diversify its export base and widen its range of customers.

I would like to see a great and growing manufacturing sector in Australia where, instead of selling wheat as wheat, we sell our wheat as flour, and instead of exporting iron and coal we export that as steal and motor cars, and then we would have a lot more job opportunities for people of all ages. We need to produce the best for less. That is the motto that Australians should be adopting because the market-place, overseas and domestic, is where people take cognisance of quality and costs. It is no use adopting a slogan of `Buy because it is Australian made'. Australians will only buy the best for the cheapest amount.

It appears to me that the Australian Government has done a reasonable job on trade matters in very difficult circumstances. We are not going to overcome the problems of trade by merely being a little fox terrier running behind the heels of the Government, yapping and criticising. We have all got to work together to overcome this problem. It is no fault of the Australian Government that overseas countries have got highly subsidised programs and that they do, in many instances, adopt unfair trading practices. But provided that we produced the required article, that we deliver it on time and that it is a top quality article at the right price, we will be able to compete.

I think that industry has to work with government. Some outstanding examples of entering into world trading markets come readily to mind. The kiwi fruit industry in Zew Zealand is paramount. It adopted a policy of exporting only quality fruit, making its packaging attractive and delivering on time. But that was not done through government intervention, and this is probably the different approach that we, in the National Party, take from that of the Liberal Party. It is our policy that the industry, as far as possible, should be self-regulating. It sets the standards. It carries out the penalties and imposes fines, et cetera, on people who try to break down the system and export an inferior product. We need to have an environment where we encourage people to get out and seek markets.

I applaud the initiative of a young man in my own area, Ian Jones, from a well known family of pork producers. He has almost finalised a contract with the People's Republic of China to send people over there to build piggeries, to provide the expert technological advice for rearing and feeding pigs and also to supply the appropriate breeding stock on a continuing basis. It will cost approximately $20m, but it will be done by private enterprise. So the Government needs to set the parameters to ensure that private enterprise has the encouragement to go out and seek markets without too much government regulation and interference. Trade, surely, is the life-blood of a successful Australia, given our relatively small population.

The second point I would like to comment on in the Supply Bills is the allocation of $26m for the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Sometimes Australians tend to downgrade themselves. We do not talk ourselves up; we tend to talk ourselves down. It is about time that that attitude finished. The Bicentennial celebrations will be a time of great celebrations for our country. It is a series of events in which all Australians should participate and should enjoy because it marks a period when we can come together as a nation and celebrate, with a unified voice, the greatness of our country and our confidence in its future. One should understand that not all Australians feel that the Bicentennial should be celebrated. They rather believe that it is time to have a wake, as it were, at the death of the nation they perceived should have remained. I can understand the feelings of our indigenous people. But I make an appeal to them, as in all things: Change is constant and nothing can be achieved if we continue to grieve over a loss or transformation.

I appeal to those within our community who feel this way about the Bicentennial celebrations to join in and come up with us in our celebrations with the aim of making our nation unified. All of us have something to learn from one another. Europeans, Australians and our Aboriginal people-people from all corners of the globe have something to contribute, both culturally and historically, to this country. In that celebration I hope the end result will be that all people-our Aboriginal people, recent migrants and the descendants of original migrants-will come out of it with self-respect. One of the great problems facing our Aboriginal people is that those of my descent unwittingly have forced the Aboriginal people to lose their self-respect. It is only when our Aboriginal community feel that their contributions, their culture and their way way of life have a meaning to the rest of us that we will have a true multicultural nation. I hope that the Bicentennial celebrations are the method by which all Australians forget about the past and work together to make this a place which enriches the lives of each and every one of us.

The next matter I want to talk about is the allocation of $123.7m to the new Parliament House. I suspect that when we originally decided to build the new Parliament House few expected that the tourist traffic through Parliament House would be estimated to be of the order of one million to one and a half million in the first year. I suspect that it is, therefore, a reasonable conclusion for us to adopt that the Parliament House will do for Canberra what the Opera House has done for Sydney. I applaud the Government. I believe it made a wise decision to restore some of the cuts in landscaping made in the last August Budget. If I had a choice, I would much rather see some of the fittings in the Parliament House not installed at the start. I would much rather have trees and more trees. One can understand the difficulties of finding finance for every conceivable object or fitting.

It appears to me that the new Parliament House surely could be, in the years to come, a forest where all the known varieties and species of Australian trees are propagated. Unfortunately, many species of trees are almost extinct. Fortunately, we have a few concerned Australians who, at sacrifice to themselves, have gone out to the desert and other areas of Australia and have preserved and propagated these trees. This is just a thought: Perhaps every school in Australia could purchase a tree from its area, send it to Canberra and thereby make a contribution to the planting and propagating of that tree. I would very much like to see a forest of trees in the environment of Parliament House. A tree takes a lifetime to grow. It would be great if, on opening day, we could proudly claim that every variety of native Australian tree was growing and, hopefully, flourishing in the immediate environs of Parliament House.

I note the allocation of $221.3m to defence. In the defence White Paper, which we debated recently in this Parliament, strong emphasis was placed on creating a self-reliant defence force. I agree with this premise because as a sovereign nation we are ultimately responsible for our own safety and security. This theme can be further expanded to include having more involvement by local Australian firms in certain areas. We should be producing the best for the lowest amount. There should be pride in one's job, and in the fact that we are competitive and that people buy from us because we can guarantee a quality product at the right price. I would like to see all our spare parts and replacement parts for our defence equipment manufactured locally. I would like to see local manufacturers supply boats, planes and surveillance equipment. The allocation of contracts for defence housing could be given to local tradesmen. These are just some of the things we tend to lose sight of when allocating macro-amounts of money. In the final analysis, government is about people.

I agree with the remarks of the honourable member for Throsby about the Department of Veterans' Affairs. When the National Party is back in government it will insist on having a Department of Veteran's Affairs. This was announced by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), the National Party shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, at a recent meeting of Vietnam veterans in Melbourne. I am glad to know that the Australian Labor Party also gives that assurance to the veterans of Australia. We respect the valour and courage of our servicemen and women. We will continue our obligations to them.

I note an allocation of $27.1m to the community care program. One of the disappointments I have as the member for Groom-no doubt that disappointment is shared by many people-is that we find it impossible to help people find places in nursing homes for their dependents and loved ones. There are nowhere near enough nursing home beds. It is about time all of us realised that modern medicine has the ability to make people old for longer. Unfortunately, it cannot make us younger for longer. People do live longer and in many instances it is necessary for them to have nursing home accommodation. I appeal to the Government, in its allocation of scarce resources, to allocate a significant amount to community care to increase the number of nursing home beds. To my mind-and I formed this opinion after discussions with many people-available nursing home accommodation is nowhere near sufficient to meet the demand.

My final comment relates to the allocation of $290m under the Commonwealth-State housing agreement. The subject of housing has been in the news often in recent times. Again I express a personal disappointment that these issues of fundamental and vital importance to every Australian are always the subject of political fighting. It would be far more beneficial to the people and to the nation if all of these fundamentally important matters could be taken out of the political arena so we could all work together to solve the problems. After food, shelter is probably the most important thing for every one of us. As back bench members of this Parliament, it is disappointing for us to be continually reminded by constituents that they are finding it increasingly difficult to save a deposit to purchase a home or, having purchased a home, are finding it difficult, because of high interest rates, to meet the repayments and thus have to trade down by selling their house and buying one which is not as commodious or is not in as nice an area as their previous house.

Obviously, if we had the right macroeconomic policies, interest rates would be much lower. People would be able to purchase their own homes. One of the great things about Australia is that we have the highest rate of home ownership, which includes people who own their own home outright and people who are in the process of purchasing one, in the free world. We can be proud of that. I suspect that it goes back to the early days of the development of our nation when it was settled by people from a poor background who did not know the value of their own private home in the country from which they came. It is this that has given people the desire to own their own homes. We need to encourage that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-(Quorum formed) I indicate to the House that I support the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1987-88, the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88. A considerable amount of money has been allocated to education. This provides me with an excellent opportunity to bring the House up to date on what has been perhaps one of the most momentous decisions of any government, affecting 1 1/2 million people who reside in the western suburbs of Sydney. Agreement has been reached between the Federal Government and the State Government to establish the Chifley University. Agreement has been reached that it should be given full autonomy status.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak on this issue not to seek any credit but to indicate that I believe it is important that the people of Australia, including members of this House, understand the important role that a collective group of Federal Labor members played throughout the campaign to establish the university. Of course, we were very fortunate in having as chairman of the group, my colleague the learned member for Lindsay (Mr Free), whose interest in education is long standing. I was pleased to act as convener, and we had a number of Ministers. In particular today, I wish to pay tribute to two honourable members who I feel played a most important role. One is a colleague of mine, the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Gorman) and the other is the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace). Their contribution was significant and vital, and without the collective spirit and determination that they provided, we would not have succeeded. Therefore, I particularly wished to mention them.

Of course, we could not achieve these sorts of results without co-operation across a great and wide field. It is true to say that State members worked closely with us-they were led by the Deputy Premier, Ron Mulock-as did local government bodies such as both Penrith Council and Blacktown City Council. Each organisation has made a unique contribution to, if I can say so, a decision of fundamental importance to 1.5 million residents of the western suburbs of Sydney. I am sure that the illustrious bearer of the name of my seat, the right honourable former Prime Minister of Australia, Ben Chifley, would derive a great deal of pride from the fact that, in a predominantly and overwhelmingly working class area of the western suburbs, we will create Chifley University.

It is fair to say that some Opposition members lent their support. However, they have been placed in a most invidious position because the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), has, on each and every occasion, failed to say that he supports the establishment of the university. It is not stretching the imagination to say that if Australia were to change government, one of the first things to go would be Chifley University. While I and others have appreciated the support of a very small number of Opposition members in the campaign, they have been placed in the contradictory position of their leader denying them. Perhaps the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) will come into the House at some date and explain his position. Does he agree with the Leader of the Opposition that the Chifley University should not be supported? Does he agree with him that it should be one of the first things to go?

Australian Labor Party members in the western suburbs have a reputation for being very active and diligent in the pursuit of the interests of their electorates. Of course, this is not the only educational issue that we have been pursuing. An equally important issue that has been as vigorously pursued is the establishment of pilot senior high schools in the western suburbs of Sydney and, perhaps, even in a country area. I welcome the announcement by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) that there will be a national goal to achieve a 65 per cent retention rate for year 12. I support that 100 per cent.

However, I have high schools in my electorate with retention rates of 14 per cent, and that is unacceptable. No matter on which side of the education debate one sits, I tell the House that that is unacceptable. I regret that the Australian Teachers Federation has singled out not only me, but also the State member for Riverstone, Richard Amery who has had the temerity, and the courage, to raise this issue-and the Deputy Premier, Ron Mulock. We have been attacked in the local papers and in the union journals for supporting the concept of a senior high school. For those who do not understand what a senior high school is, I can tell them that it is a high school exclusively devoted to years 11 and 12.

In supporting the concept of a senior high school, it has never been our position that where comprehensive high schools are working successfully they should be changed. All we say is that we accept and acknowledge the fact that comprehensive high schools are not working successfully in many parts of the western suburbs. Given the leaked figures on retention rates-and I regret that they are not published automatically in New South Wales-there are other areas with equally strong claims to a senior high school. Wollongong would be one area, and Newcastle another. I say to my National Party of Australia colleagues that, indeed, certain provincial cities and country areas would benefit from an approach other than the comprehensive high school.

I am wedded, as are all of my colleagues on the Government benches, to the idea that the children of Australia have a fundamental right to equality of opportunity, and an important aspect of that is equality of educational opportunity. That is not the case in my area. In my electorate, the average number of students in year 12 is about 30. It is very difficult for the teachers to provide a comprehensive choice of subjects, let alone subjects of different degrees of difficulty. It sounds very logical to want to amalgamate all those students in one high school and provide a much greater variety of subjects and also a choice of subjects of different degrees of difficulty. That is one of the reasons why we support the concept of senior high schools.

Let us examine what we are being accused of in supporting that. Firstly, we are accused of being elitist. People say that we want to set up elitist senior high school. Frankly, I think that it is far more elitist to allow a working class electorate in a working class suburb to have only 14 per cent of its students staying until year 12. That is the height of elitism, and I reject it. I will oppose it and fight it at every opportunity.

The other suggestion is that we should not try out the high schools in a working class area. It is said that the concept has some merit, but let it be tried in the North Shore and the eastern suburbs because they are more academically inclined. Indeed, if we look at performance, perhaps they are more academically inclined. However there is one thing on which I would not backtrack as long as I am in this Parliament, and that is that there is anything inferior about the young people of my electorate or neighbouring electorates. When we talk about skills, ability, intelligence and what the students are capable of doing, I will take no backward steps. I will have no government trying to entrench the view that there is something different about those students. As I said earlier, the North Shore and the eastern suburbs are doing very well, so why change them? We should be looking for changes in areas where the system is not working.

I would have liked to have raised other matters in my modest contribution, but time will not allow that. Therefore, I shall end by saying that I, nor anyone on the platform for a senior high school, have never ever suggested that there are single shot solutions to the problem. What we have said is that we must start somewhere, and this appears to be the most important and radical first step that needs to be taken. There will be other issues and other problems that we will need to work through with the parents, students and, most importantly, the teachers. I look forward to that co-operation; I look forward to working through the problems. However, if we are opposed on the concept of a senior high school, that is fair enough and we will fight it out in the forum of public opinion and decision making. I am encouraged to think that some of those forums might be the annual conference of the Australian Labor Party and New South Wales in June and the parliamentary Caucus in Macquarie Street. I have every confidence that Labor members whether members of parliament, members of the party or members of trade unions-will be as equally concerned and compassionate as are my colleagues and I on this side of the House, and I predict that we will be successful in the fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather ironic that the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1987-88, the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88 should be debated today, the day of the so-called mini-Budget of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We all hope, however, that the mini-Budget will make a small start on the immense project of winding back government expenditure. There have been two false starts already-last year's mini-Budget and last year's Budget, both of which were supposed to reduce government expenditure. In neither case has significant progress genuinely been made. Tonight is the real opportunity for the Government to start winding back the dreadful national problem of government spending.

SPEECH.PARA: Ever since the Government was elected it has talked about the need to reduce government expenditure. That is ironic because, in spite of the Government's rhetoric, the reality has been entirely the reverse. Government spending under this Government has increased year after year. Yet every year the Government talks about the importance of restraint and reducing expenditure. It is important when talking about government expenditure to understand it in its proper context in Australia today. When this Government came to power in 1983 Australia was in the midst of an international economic slump which had obviously done a great deal of harm to the economy. The Government at that time made no excuse about that and did not try to run away from it. It was a fact of economic life. We were also enduring the worst drought Australia has had this century. As a consequence, there was an increase in government spending in the 1982-83 financial year. The economic downturn made that increase an inevitability, as regrettable as it may have been.

The tragedy of this Government is that when it came to power international circumstances and climatic circumstances within Australia had both changed, yet the policy of expanding government outlays continued at an accelerated pace. At a time when the global economy was recovering and the drought was coming to an end this Government should have wound back expenditure, not increased it. Yet in 1983, 1984 and 1985 the Government increased expenditure again, again and again.

When one looks at the figures one can see the devastation caused by the big spending policies of the Hawke Government. For each of the four years of the Hawke Government the average figure for real growth in government expenditure has been 3.9 per cent per annum, whereas under the Fraser Government-including its last year, a year of grave economic difficulties-the increase in spending was only 2.1 per cent. The average figure for the share of gross domestic product taken up by Federal government spending, setting aside State and local government expenditure, is 29.9 per cent under the Hawke Government compared to an average figure of 27.7 per cent under the Fraser Government. In each of the four Hawke Government Budgets government spending has exceeded previous records. So every year the Government has been in power it has spent more money than any of the governments that preceded it.

The cumulative deficits created by this Government's spending add up, in just four years, to nearly $24 billion, compared to a total of $17.6 billion over the seven years of the Fraser Government. It is not surprising that as a result of this significant, almost fantastic, increase in government expenditure under the Hawke Government the Australian economy and Australian society have encountered severe difficulties, structural problems and dislocation. The people today who are talking about reducing government expenditure are not ideologues. They are not people in the New Right, the new Left, the new Centre or whatever it may be. They are ordinary people who understand that this enormous increase in government expenditure is ruining this country economically and socially.

The economic consequences of big government spending are all too obvious for everyone to see. The appalling growth in Australia's foreign debt since this Government has been in power was raised again with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Question Time, but he chose not to address it. When his Government came to power in 1983 our foreign debt was $35 billion. Today it is $105 billion. It has tripled under the tutelage of the Hawke Government. There is no international excuse for this Government, no way it can run away from the fact that its policies of economic mismanagement have sent this country broke to the extent that every baby born today in Australia inherits a debt of $6,000. That is a shameful statistic and something all Australians should be worried about.

When we look at the effect of this Government's spending on interest rates we see that not only have interest rates reached their highest level since the Great Depression but also that the ordinary Australian paying off his or her mortgage is paying $26 a week more than he or she was paying under the Fraser Government. The handmaiden of big government is high taxation. The same consequence has come about in regard to taxation as a result of this Government's spending policies. When this Government came to power the average single income family with two children was paying $65 a week in taxation. Today it is paying $102 a week-an increase in its weekly tax bill, even taking into consideration the so-called tax cuts which are to come next month, of an incredible $35 a week. Honourable members on the other side of the House ought to be ashamed of these statistics. They ought to hang their heads in shame when they go out into the community, given the record of economic devastation their big spending policies have brought on ordinary families. Their big taxing and big spending policies have drained incentive from this community, from entrepreneurs and from employees who might otherwise have worked overtime. We have ended up with an economy which in the last year or so has declined. They are the economic consequences of big spending. We know them well. But they must be understood throughout the community.

Big government spending has also had severe social consequences. Big government spending by the Whitlam Government and the Hawke Government has developed a welfare culture in Australia. There is a generation of Australians now who have grown up expecting support from the Government and who have had the spirit of entrepreneurship driven away from them by cultural change brought about by big government spending. So many people are sitting around like junkies, waiting for their next fix of government grants. This big spending has undermined the sense of community responsibility that was once such an important part of Australian civilisation so that when there is a social problem in a local community people no longer ask what they can do to resolve the problem. All they do is ask which level of government is going to sort out the problem. That is sad and tragic. No government, State or Federal, with all the money in the world, can ever provide the same compassionate care for the elderly, the disadvantaged and the unemployed as neighbours, friends and local communities can provide. Yet big spending is destroying that form of compassionate care amongst individuals.

When it comes to the creative parts of Australian culture one can see the same thing happening. In the area of the arts, for which I am the shadow Minister, we find once more that this welfare culture has developed. Race Mathews, the Victorian Minister for the Arts, said this about the attitude towards grants in the arts community as a result of the policies of this Government and the Whitlam Government:

Looking back to the Whitlam years, I think we did the country a bad turn by introducing the concept of government grants to single interests groups. Many community groups are convinced they can't do anything unless they get a grant. I'm not sure that the number of groups allowed to do worthwhile things by grants is not outweighed by the number which are convinced they can't do anything without grants except criticise.

They are very telling remarks. Elwyn Lynn, a very distinguished arts journalists and a former Chairman of the Visual Arts Board of the Australia Council, said this about the effect of excessive grants on the arts community:

. . . one does have to acknowledge the view that the Visual Arts Board has fostered dependence on grants and has undermined self-reliance . . . Some aspects of art have become as bureaucratised as much as art behind the elastic and iron curtains. Such management may be necessary but it is replete with careerism.

That is a damning comment, and one that the Government should take note of, and yet just recently the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) was quoted as saying: `Calls to reduce expenditure on the arts because of Australia's current economic conditions were nonsense'. So, apparently expenditure for pensioners, the elderly and the unemployed can be reduced but one should never reduce spending in the arts area. I do not want spending in the arts area to be destroyed and I am not arguing for that. I am arguing for equity and common sense when it comes to government expenditure in this area. It is something that we have lost.

The Government boasts that it has increased spending on the arts. It boasts only in terms of quantity, but what about the quality of that spending? One finds that the quality of that spending is really quite extraordinary. The Australia Council gave a grant of $11,000 to the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union so that it could commission a painting of the Cockatoo dockyards, that painting to be hung in the union's own office. That is an extraordinary waste of taxpayers' money and yet is defined as being spending to assist the arts. It is not spending to assist the arts but spending designed simply to prop up a trade union. Over the past year or so the Waste Watch Committee has alluded to many other examples, but I will not repeat all of those as my time has certainly almost run out.

In conclusion, I point out that this is a very small example of the way that this Government and its Labor predecessor, the Whitlam Government, have gone mad with spending and with providing grants. It has destroyed the economy because of its obsession with big spending. Equally importantly, it is destroying with big spending. Equally importantly, it is destroying the fabric of Australian society by changing attitudes and developing a whole welfare culture, matters in relation to which, apropos the statement to be made tonight and its Budget to be handed down later this year, the Government will find very hard to unravel. I hope that the Government has the courage to make the hard decisions tonight that it has failed to make in the past.
